797. Scott Norman Frederick
SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES

No. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer so don't worry about leaving blank spaces. Use extra sheets of paper if there is not sufficient space to answer the questions. Don't hesitate to give details, or describe particular events, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 1, entitled "Pioneer Dist: What Did Western Canadian Pioneers Eat?" is still being circulated. If you have not already answered this, and would be willing to do so, please put a check mark here ( ) and one will be sent to you.

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires on other subjects will be prepared at a later date. Some of these are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

( ) All questionnaires
( ) Pioneer health conditions
( ) Pioneer social life, sports and recreation
( ) Pioneer housing
( ) Pioneer education and churchwork
( ) Pioneer farming experience

Preservation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives Board's Office at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our Province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.
SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRE

No. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

1. Your full name: SCOTT NORMAN FREDERICK

2. Your address: 718, EAST LAKE, AXE, SASKATOON

3. Date: March 20th, 1952

4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country): Peterborough, Ontario, Canada

5. What was your father's name and occupation? Robert Scott - Farmer

6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year): July 1904

7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible:
   Souris, Manitoba 1900
   Elgin, Manitoba 1901-1902
   Winnipeg, Portage la Prairie, Brandon 1903-1904

8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was a small child", "I was in my teens", etc.): Twenty-one

9. What were your reasons for coming West? Not needed on the old farm. I had no definite object as to occupation but having no education or training for anything else I gradually settled down and decided to acquire some land and make a start on my own account.

10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?):
    I had a great many relatives in the West, mostly in Manitoba and it was through information gained from them I was influenced to go to Western Canada.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?
They were all highly favorable to it.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?
I traveled with my grandfather who was making the trip to visit sons and daughters.

13. What means of transportation did you use?
Railroad

14. What incidents of the Journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement, etc.).
No particular incident, no accidents or much excitement.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?
Saskatoon

16. Where did you settle or take up land?
Saskatoon

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.
Saskatoon since November 1st, 1939.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?
Worked on my father's farm 6 miles north of Peterborough.
On farms, lumber camps and railroad construction.
After 1906 lived steadily on my own farm.
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?
   About once a month.

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date
    and place of marriage.
   Janet G. Campbell, August 4th, 1915 - Jennette

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommending it as a place
    to settle?
   No knowledge of such.

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West
    tell when they came and where they settled.
   Sister, April 1906 - Later married and settled at Kinley, Sask.
   Sister July 1908 - Later married and went to live at Grande Prairie.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your
    memory which you would like to record?
   No particular experience, just went through all the stages of pioneering on the prairie
   first a sod house and barn, then horses and steam threshing outfit followed by more modern farm machinery.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (For business, attending church,
    visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far? By what means of travel?
   Not a great deal, but did haul two crops of wheat to Saskatoon, driving a team of horses, leading another with second load
   horse and buggy a distance of seven miles to church in country school.
   Have done some travelling since, been in Toronto Hamilton, H. Cuthbert, Niagara Falls
   and Windsor in Ontario; Detroit Chicago and
   H. Paul Minneapolis and Fargo U.S., also Seattle
   and Portland - Have been over all West Canada.
25. When was the first car used in the community? Model T Ford

26. If you owned a car before 1911, when did you buy it? What make?

27. Where was your trading center? How far from your home? First Saskatoon, 35 miles; Asquith 11 miles; Jenneta 5 miles.

28. Did you continue to trade there? (Indicate any changes due to new towns appearing, better means of travel, etc.)

Yes more or less: conditions steadily improved with wood construction and improved equipment.

29. How often did you shop in the early days? First once a month, later generally once a week.

30. When (if ever) did people in your district first start going to town regularly on Saturdays?

I believe it got to be something of a habit after 1910 except during seeding and harvest.

31. When (if ever) did you first begin to buy through the mail order catalogue? What kind of articles did you buy in this way? Indicate also what fraction of your total purchases were by mail order and any changes in the proportion of purchases made by mail order since the pioneer period.

I probably started to buy from mail order catalogues about 1905. Mostly clothing about 10. The proportion has gradually decreased.

32. When did you first have a telephone and what company provided it? 1912 Jenneta Telephone Co. later amalgamated with Asquith.

33. When you came to Saskatchewan the first time was it with the idea of staying permanently? Or did you make up your mind after trying it out? When did you make this decision?

No idea what I wanted. Decided after trying it out in 1905.
34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1924? What reasons did they have for moving?

Yes
Homesteaders sold out to neighbors

35. Did many people move away during the 1930's? Did many return?

No

36. If you or some member of your family have held public office, or have been active in any organizations, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

Junior Secretary of an Women's Association
1908 to 1920
Secretary of School District 1918 to 1932
Municipal Councillor Prince R.M. 1914 to 1916

37. If you or any of your family or friends were "first" to have or do something in the district mention it here giving dates wherever possible. (Such as owning the first automobile, combine, organizing the first lodge, etc.)

None

38. How did the places in your community get their names? (School districts, Post Offices, villages, railway stations, creeks, hills, etc.). Try to give: (1) name and occupation of person suggesting place-name (2) origin and meaning of the name (3) date of its adoption (4) any changes in names since the first name was given date and reason for change. Give facts of new name as above in (1), (2), (3).

1. School District - Fairholme - named by myself.
2. Jurriata Railroad Station received its name because of the alphabetical method followed in naming towns on the National Transcontinental
39. Questions regarding historical source materials:

Do you have in your possession or do you know the whereabouts of diaries, old letters, old posters and programs, minute books of community organizations, old pamphlets, old photographs, written recollections and reminiscences? (Describe)

Nothing except a copy of the programme of the 1st Plowing Match held west of Saskatoon near Kinley Park.

Would you or the person who owns them either

(1) be willing to lend them to the Provincial Archivist for copying?

(2) be willing to present them to the Archives Division of the Legislative Library, Regina, or the Archives Office at the University in Saskatoon?.... (indicate your preference, if any)

40. If you have children or grandchildren, please give their names, where they live and occupations.

41. What do you think are the most important changes in your community since you first came West?

The steady move to larger farms, with large power machinery, consequently a heavy decrease in population. The great difficulty in keeping schools open, with so few children.

Please give the names and addresses of other pioneers who could answer this questionnaire.

Archer Geo. H. Harris 607-3rd Ave. North
John Seymour Junior Sask
Geo. H. Butledge 214-27th St. West.

If someone else has filled in this questionnaire for you, please have this person give name and address here:
